Award.AwardTitle: Mathematical Record Keeping Supports Cognition and Communication (MaRKS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project conducts an exploration of elements of geometric mathematics tasks that promote students' record keeping (RK) strategies that facilitate student cognition during problem solving and aid in communication about how solutions were obtained. The project addresses three questions: (1) What features of mathematics task presentation promote record keeping that aid middle grades students cognition and communication? (2) What principles can be derived and applied for designing tasks to promote useful record keeping? (3) How does student performance differ on tasks designed with supports for record keeping versus tasks without such supports? Are there different impacts for English Language Learners (ELL) versus non-ELL students?

The project uses the framework of Cognitive Load Theory (CLT) to guide the work. A variety of methods will be used in the study, including student observations and interviews, design and testing of tasks and creation of a rubric, and an experiment that uses tasks with and without RK supports, particularly noting impacts for ELL students.

The study's findings has immediate relevance for mathematics instruction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Mathematical Record Keeping Supports Cognition and Communication (MaRKS) project investigated how mathematics tasks can support middle grades students to write and draw during their mathematical work in ways that support them in solving the tasks and communicating about their mathematical thinking. The project developed a framework of features that can be integrated into mathematical tasks to encourage students to write and draw as part of their mathematical work and conducted an experiment to investigate how well tasks designed to support mathematical writing and drawing led to improved mathematical problem-solving and communication. Given the particular challenges for English learners in communicating in the mathematics classroom and in making sense of mathematics tasks presented in a language they are still learning, the project included a focus on how tasks designed to support mathematical writing and drawing can help students who are English learners.  Over the course of the project, 113 students participated in videotaped sessions where they shared their thinking about mathematics tasks during study of how those tasks led to writing and drawing that helped students in their problem-solving and communication. 

Intellectual Merit

The MaRKS study included research questions focused on the features of mathematics tasks that promote writing and drawing to support students and on how students’ mathematical performance differs when mathematics tasks support their use of writing and drawing. The study built on existing research about mathematics task design, mathematical problem solving and communication, and how students manage the demands of challenging mathematical work.  Task design features to support students to write and draw during mathematical work that were identified included:  diagrams large enough to write in and around, extra copies of diagrams to draft ideas, blank space for working, “scrap” paper for experimenting, separate and designated areas for answering, and checklists or space for self-monitoring progress.  The study of student performance based on support for writing and drawing indicated that the use of written and drawn records supported successful problem solving and communication, and that English learners were more successful in solving tasks when they were designed to promote writing and drawing during problem solving.

Broader Impacts

The MaRKS study produced frameworks and findings that have potential use by mathematics teachers, mathematics coaches, curriculum designers, and mathematics education researchers as they make task selection and task design decisions to support students’ mathematical learning and communication.  A manuscript that is in preparation at the end of this project, a previously published journal article, and several research presentations from the MaRKS research:

  • Document features of tasks that can support writing and drawing as part of students’ mathematical work;
  • Provide examples of how writing and drawing can support students’ problem-solving and their communication about mathematics, including by students who are English learners; and
  • Share findings about the positive relationship between students’ use of writing/drawing and success in solving problems, and the positive relationship between tasks designed to promote writing/drawing and English learning students’ success in solving problems.

Examples from the project’s research are included in this report to illustrate the ways in which mathematics tasks that are designed to promote students’ writing and drawing during mathematical work can support those students in their problem-solving and mathematical communication.
